#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=Peter Dorschel
#Text=The Holy Loch seen across the Firth of Clyde from Tower Hill , Gourock , with Hunters Quay on the left , and Strone to the right
#Text=Location of the Holy Loch in Scotland
#Text=Peter Dorschel was an East German spy convicted in Scotland in June 1967 of offences contrary to the Official Secrets Act , involving the sale of information to the USSR .
#Text=Background
#Text=Peter Dorschel was a ship 's cook . [ 1 ]

#Text=Little is known of his background other than that he came from what was then the German Democratic Republic ( East Germany ) and had visited Britain on occasion prior to 1967 when employed as a seaman .
#Text=He had worked legally under the English permit system [ 2 ] and in January 1967 had married Christine , an English model , at Lübeck . [ 3 ]
#Text=Some time prior to May 1967 , and probably during his honeymoon , he had been approached in his home country by two compatriots who were operating as agents for the USSR .

#Text=They proposed to provide finances enabling Dorschel to acquire a small hotel in Dunoon , Scotland , by use of which he would be able to obtain information from local US service personnel regarding fleet movements and facilities at their Polaris nuclear submarine base at the Holy Loch .
#Text=The information would be passed on by Dorschel to the agents .
#Text=In April , Dorschel rented a house at Hunter 's Quay .
#Text=This provided him with a good view of activity at the Polaris base . [ 2 ]
#Text=Arrest and trial
#Text=Dorschel was living at 10 Webster Grove , Prestwich , England , when he was arrested on 26 May 1967 in connection with his activities . [ 3 ] [ 4 ]

#Text=Then aged 26 , he was accused of inciting another man , William Alexander MacAffer ( sometimes spelled McAffer ) , " to obtain documents which might be or were intended to be directly or indirectly useful to an enemy , for a purpose prejudicial to the safety or interests of the State . " [ 5 ]
#Text=MacAffer was a 30-year-old bookmaker [ 6 ] who lived at Argyll Street in Dunoon .

#Text=Another who was involved in the conspiracy was Garry Lee Ledbetter , [ 7 ] a US Navy shipfitter from Dexter , Missouri , US [ 1 ] who was stationed on USS Simon Lake , the submarine tender serving the Polaris fleet at Holy Loch .
#Text=Ledbetter supplied two documents to MacAffer , who in turn supplied them to Dorschel . [ 2 ]
#Text=USS Simon Lake at Kings Bay in 1981
#Text=Although arrested and initially charged in Manchester , the case against Dorschel was transferred to Scotland when related arrests were made there . [ 5 ]
#Text=Dorschel pleaded guilty on 19 June 1967 at Dunoon Sheriff Court . [ 7 ]
#Text=With Nicholas Fairbairn acting in his defence at the High Court of Justiciary in Edinburgh , Dorschel was sentenced on 23 June to seven years ' imprisonment . [ 2 ]
#Text=Having heard the prosecutor describe Dorschel as a probably a " little fish " and amateurish , the sentencing judge recorded that
#Text=This case , I am satisfied , is by no means as serious as some which have happened in recent years [ in England ] .
#Text=Nevertheless , it appears that this was only through the efficient work of the security services that your activities were stopped before real tragedies occurred .
#Text=I agree that you were perhaps ... a little fish in this particular sea of trouble .
#Text=Nevertheless , these charges are always grave and serious ... [ 2 ]

#Text=The Times reported that , despite the seriousness of the charge , the court hearing had been " marked by some moments of levity on the public benches and drolleries from the legal participants " .

#Text=One instance giving rise to this was a statement regarding Dorschel 's naivety : he had been asked to supply photographs of Hythe and Poole to his spymasters and had instead sent picture postcards .
#Text=Fairbairn noted that " If this is how foreign espionage in matters as important as nuclear submarines is conducted , we have little to fear from it . " [ 8 ]
#Text=Alleged accomplices
#Text=Dorschel had co-operated from the outset with the investigation and Fairbairn said that he had received no training nor had any particular ideological basis for his activities .
#Text=At the time of Dorschel 's sentencing , the US Navy reported that investigations were still proceeding with regard to Ledbetter . [ 2 ]
#Text=Later , Ledbetter was charged by the Navy with supplying a training booklet and another unspecified document to a man and a woman .
#Text=Dorschel gave evidence in camera against Ledbetter at the court martial in August 1967 . [ 9 ]
#Text=MacAffer and his sister , Frances Isabella MacAffer ( or Hardless ] , [ 10 ]
#Text=both attended but refused to supply information . [ 9 ]
#Text=Ledbetter , who had been subjected to a polygraph test , [ 11 ] was found guilty .
#Text=He was sentenced to six months ' hard labour and discharged from the navy . [ 12 ]
#Text=Although charges had been laid against MacAffer , they were dropped in September 1967 .
#Text=The Crown Office , who were responsible for prosecuting , said that it was unable to provide a reason for this . [ 12 ]

#Text=MacAffer , whose sister was the girlfriend of Ledbetter , then claimed that he had notified the US and British authorities of Dorschel 's initial approach to him and had been trying to trap Dorschel since that time .
#Text=He also claimed that he had been told there were six East Germans involved in the spy ring .
#Text=Official bodies of both countries denied his claims of co-operation . [ 13 ]
#Text=MacAffer faced further charges in October 1967 , relating to alleged avoidance of customs duty and illegal off-course bookmaking that had been discovered in May . [ 14 ] [ 15 ]
#Text=Later events
#Text=Dorschel was released in January 1970 and deported to West Germany . [ 3 ]
#Text=Later in that year , his wife , Christine , who had been aged 21 at the time of the trial and had promised to " stand by " him , [ 2 ] divorced him on the grounds of cruelty .
#Text=In granting the decree nisi , the judge chose to overlook her admitted adultery .
#Text=She said at the time of the divorce that she thought Dorschel was possibly serving in the merchant navy of the USSR . [ 3 ]
